Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Melting in the Off-Axis Environment - Interdisciplinary Field and Modeling Studies of the 8 20'N Seamount Chain, EPR
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how melts are generated and focused across hundreds of kilometers through the upper mantle to the narrow mid-ocean ridge (MOR) axis is fundamental to understanding how Earth's ocean crust is formed and how elements and heat are exchanged between the interior of our planet and its surface. Significant advancements have been made in the use of computer models to investigate mantle melting and melt transport. However, the lack of complementary geophysical and geochemical data from the same area is a critical information gap that needs to be filled before progress can be made in refining present models. This research entails a multidisciplinary geophysical and geochemical program to map, sample, and analyze samples from the 8Â°20'N Seamount Chain that extends 200 km westward from the East Pacific Rise Siqueiros ridge-transform intersection in the Pacific Ocean. Seamounts provide a unique opportunity to test hypotheses of melt distribution and source variation that occur away from spreading centers. Melts that build these seamounts provide geochemical windows into the upper mantle.

The research includes an oceanographic cruise to map and sample the targeted region. This will be followed by geophysical data processing and petrographic, petrologic, and geochemical analyses of samples collected by both using ALVIN, a manned deep submersible, and dredging. Goals of the research are to develop new, integrated models for upper lithosphere structure, deformation, and melt distribution at a fast-spreading center and investigate the dynamics of off-axis melting. The approach is interdisciplinary and includes analysis of geophysical and geochemical data and geodynamic modeling. Rock samples will be analyzed for all major and trace elements and radiogenic isotopes of Nd, Sr, and Pb will also be analyzed. Broader impacts of the project include creation of a marine geology curricular unit targeted at the middle school level and compliant with Next Generation Sciences Standards that have currently been adopted by 45 states. The project involves working closely with teachers and administrators of Pipkin Middle School, a nationally ranked Title I school that serves 580 students in the low-income center-city of Springfield, MO (poverty index of 78%). The teachers will work closely with the reserachers and both parties will jointly create the educational materials. Emphasis will be placed on inquiry learning and connecting fundamental science processes with current research. The pilot implementation will coincide with the proposed field program. The developed unit will be made broadly available via the web on curricular resource sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geophysical and geochemical studies of mid-ocean ridge (MOR) spreading centers over the past few decades have provided geoscientists with a wealth of information about the composition of the upper mantle where magmas are generated and how the crust and lithospheric plates of the ocean form. Although the bulk of oceanic crust is formed by volcanism at the ridge crests, there are thousands of submerged small- to moderate-sized volcanoes, often in linear chains that add to and sit on top of the seafloor. The origin of these volcanic seamounts and their relationship to spreading ridges continues to be debated - in part because few have been studied in detail. Sparse sampling and geochemical analyses of seamounts scattered throughout the Pacific suggest that the near ridge mantle has far greater compositional variability then is preserved the axis of the ridges where mixing is common. Further, because these near-axis seamounts commonly form above the region where MOR melting occurs, they can provide a window into the processes that occur and compositions of the sub-ridge mantle.

In 2016 and 2018, during two OASIS cruises (Off-Axis Seamount Investigations at Siqueiros), we completed geophysical, observational, and geochemical investigations of a nearly continuous chain of seamounts that was previously unexplored extending ~200 km west of the East Pacific Rise (EPR) axis. Using shipboard remote sensing and the human occupied submersible (HOV) Alvin together with the autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) we observed, mapped and sampled the so-called “8°20’N seamount chain”. Our initial results showed them to be younger than expected, composed of a remarkable variety of basaltic rock not typically recovered on the EPR and that some of the seamounts had previous hydrothermal and biologic activity.  Preliminary petrologic and geochemical investigations have revealed extreme compositional variability in the near MOR mantle that was previously only surmised from the regional seamount studies done in the northeast Pacific. There is no systematic variability in composition along the chain and even individual seamounts can have highly variable chemistries, suggesting that the mantle is heterogeneous on very small spatial scales. The location, orientation, and preliminary data from the 8°20'N seamount chain make it an ideal a natural laboratory to further investigate source heterogeneity, melting systematics and plate geodynamics in the near-ridge mantle. Our initial results suggest various amounts of melting of the heterogeneous mantle at a range of depths may produce some of the observed chemical variations.  

As part of this project we trained young faculty members at two institutions (Boise State and U. Illinois) to conducting complex MGG/deep submergence based field studies. In addition, both graduate and undergraduate students from 5 institutions (U. Illinois, U. Florida, LDEO, Skidmore College, Bates College) were trained in at-sea data acquisition and processing methods involving EM122 multibeam, underway geophysics (gravity and magnetics) and Alvin and Sentry vehicle data.  All students had the opportunity to dive in Alvin, interpret the geology and describe lava samples. Initial scientific results from this project have been presented in 9 conference proceedings and resulted in a Senior Honors Thesis at UF and a Masters Thesis at Boise State. We also ran an educational program in 2016 with the Campus Middle School for Girls on the U. Illinois campus for 6-8th grade teachers that developed a cross-disciplinary curricular unit that followed the OASIS field expedition, allowing students to participate first hand in conducting science at sea. The 2018 cruise was followed by an NSF - Early Career Scientist Training Cruise to the EPR that involved at sea training 11 early career scientists and pre-cruise webinars. It was followed by a public outreach event on the dock in San Diego.
